Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Urbanization, Development, and Labor Migration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project investigates how state development initiatives in non-liberal political contexts shape labor migration and urbanization. Urban populations now account for over half of the world's population, with the proportion projected to grow to two-thirds by the mid-21st century. Of this increase, 90% is expected to take place in developing countries, including those with authoritarian governments. This research project investigates how urban labor migration, a key driver of this projected urbanization, can be catalyzed by development projects that may seem to have little to do with migration, such as those that subsidize rural house construction. It analyzes how these development projects shape ideas about modernity and how these in turn encourage migration. It also investigates how urban migration shapes senses of self and identity, and how these work with or against states' attempts to govern their populations. The project's findings will be widely disseminated via academic and non-academic outlets. Results are relevant to policy-makers, NGOs, and development organizations concerned with the social impacts of rapid urbanization throughout the developing world.

Using qualitative (participant observation, semi-structured interviews, surveys, and textual and discourse analysis) field-gathered data, this project examines the relationship between development as a rationale of rule and its actual accomplishment, and how state power (re)shapes desires vis-a-vis housing as a form of development. The project contributes to the field of development geography through its investigation of governmentality and modernity in an authoritarian, non-Western context. It also contributes to the geography of migration by analyzing how cultural politics and political-economic factors come together in producing labor migration, and how the experience of labor migration shapes migrant and urban subjectivities. This study investigates these broad questions by asking how and why villagers make the decisions they do with respect to accepting and spending on housing projects; how and why they make decisions about labor migration; and how urban living experiences change their aspirations and identities. Although this project uses a case study of Tibetans in Qinghai province, China, its approach and findings has applicability in many other places experiencing rapid urbanization. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this project will also provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This dissertation research project explored how state development initiatives, specifically the housing subsidy projects, shaped rural-urban labor migration and urbanization. It analyzed how the housing projects as a form of development influences ideas about modernity and how urban migration shapes sense of self and identity. Drawing on ethnographic research conducted in Amdo, situated in the northeastern Tibetan Plateau, this research project examined how development produces new governable subjects and spaces in China's Tibet. By critically analyzing the distribution of cash subsidies for housing construction as a form of statist development in Amdo, findings show that the housing subsidy projects are not only supposed to improve standards of living for Tibetan farmers, but that the projects are also techniques that produce governable, consumer subjects among Tibetan populations. The projects at the same time increase income disparities among Tibetan households in the same village.

Drawing on feminist approach to migration geography, this research examines how state-led housing projects and shifting markers of status intersect to shape Tibetan labor migration. Rather than conceiving of Tibetan labor migration as merely economic processes of housebuilding through migrant wages, this research treats the spatial mobility of Tibetan labor migration as a social and political process by paying attention to the politics of meanings ascribed to the migration process. Focusing on status within the households as a scale in a spatial migration process, this project sheds light on socially and politically constructed Tibetan labor migration processes from rural villages to urban centers. The findings show that the role of the state, in the implementation of housing subsidy projects, is influential not only in shifting the markers of household status but it is also persuasive in shaping and speeding up the recent flow of Tibetan labor migration to cities. That is, Tibetan labor migration is not merely an economic process of housing construction, but also a political process. It further delineates the power relations that reinforce the migration flows to produce and reproduce governable subjects among Tibetan populations. 

The co-PI will share results through reports and memos written in both Tibetan and Chinese languages for policy makers at the local and regional governmental departments, as actual policymaking in China happens through such channels rather than official reports. I established relationship with most of these government officials during my field research in Qinghai from July 2018 to August 2019. Findings will be communicated to the broader academic community in English through journal articles and presentations at professional conferences. As of December 2019, the co-PI presented the findings at several professional conferences, including: 2019 AAG Regional Annual Meeting in Kansas in October 2019; The Fifteenth Seminar of the International Association for Tibetan Studies in Paris in July 2019; and, Association for Asian Studies Annual Conference in Denver in March 2019. A detailed ethnographic exploration of Tibetan villagers' participation in two state-led housing subsidy projects has been published in Critical Asian Studies (Zhaxi 2019). Although the research project focuses on Tibetan farmers in China, it presents significantly broader applications as countries throughout the Global South undergo rapid urbanization.
